question.title: Hibernate annotation to a transient collection field

node.contents: I would like a collection field to use a query, but I cannot find a way to do it. There is a @Formula annotation, but that doesn't work with collections. You might ask why I just don't use @ManyToMany or similar annotation. The thing is, I have a table (say, called Relationships) with columns similar to this:

astNode.text: I would like a collection field to use a query, but I cannot find a way to do it. There is a @Formula annotation, but that doesn't work with collections. You might ask why I just don't use @ManyToMany or similar annotation. The thing is, I have a table (say, called Relationships) with columns similar to this:

node.contents: Now, the ChildType and ParentType can be one of many classes in my application, therefore I cannot (I don't want to) use @ManyToMany mapping, since it will create another table for each class. What I would like is, to have a collection field called relationships in, say, class A, that would select all rows (relationships) from Relationship table, where ChildID = A.id and ChildType = 'A'. Is that possible?

astNode.text: Now, the ChildType and ParentType can be one of many classes in my application, therefore I cannot (I don't want to) use @ManyToMany mapping, since it will create another table for each class. What I would like is, to have a collection field called relationships in, say, class A, that would select all rows (relationships) from Relationship table, where ChildID = A.id and ChildType = 'A'. Is that possible?

node.contents: Update: Looks like I haven't made myself clear enough. Ok, say, I have a class Relationship where ParentType and ChildType are just class names of parent and child as a String:

astNode.text: Update: Looks like I haven't made myself clear enough. Ok, say, I have a class Relationship where ParentType and ChildType are just class names of parent and child as a String:

elements.contents: @Entity public class Relationship { @Id @GeneratedValue private Long id; @Enumerated(EnumType.STRING) private ParentType parentType; private Long parentId; @Enumerated(EnumType.STRING) private ParentType childType; private Long childId; }

units.rawText: @Entity public class Relationship { @Id @GeneratedValue private Long id; @Enumerated(EnumType.STRING) private ParentType parentType; private Long parentId; @Enumerated(EnumType.STRING) private ParentType childType; private Long childId; }

node.contents: Then I have all kinds of classes that have a field relationships, say:

astNode.text: Then I have all kinds of classes that have a field relationships, say:

elements.contents: @Entity public class A { @Id @GeneratedValue private Long id; private Set<Relationship> relationships = new HashSet<Relationship>(); } @Entity public class B { @Id @GeneratedValue private Long id; private Set<Relationship> relationships = new HashSet<Relationship>(); } @Entity public class C { @Id @GeneratedValue private Long id; private Set<Relationship> relationships = new HashSet<Relationship>(); }

units.rawText: @Entity public class A { @Id @GeneratedValue private Long id; private Set<Relationship> relationships = new HashSet<Relationship>(); } @Entity public class B { @Id @GeneratedValue private Long id; private Set<Relationship> relationships = new HashSet<Relationship>(); } @Entity public class C { @Id @GeneratedValue private Long id; private Set<Relationship> relationships = new HashSet<Relationship>(); }

node.contents: Now I want Hibernate to query the Relationships table to find the relationships for each class, A, B, and C whenever I get an instance bean of corresponding class. Something like this:

astNode.text: Now I want Hibernate to query the Relationships table to find the relationships for each class, A, B, and C whenever I get an instance bean of corresponding class. Something like this:

elements.contents: @Query("(select relationship from Relationship relationship where relationship.childId = id and relationship.childType = 'A')") private Set<Relationship> relationships = new ArrayList<Relationship>();

node.valueRep: "(select relationship from Relationship relationship where relationship.childId = id and relationship.childType = 'A')"

units.rawText: @Query("(select relationship from Relationship relationship where relationship.childId = id and relationship.childType = 'A')") private Set<Relationship> relationships = new ArrayList<Relationship>();

node.contents: I did a workaround for now, but I would still like to know if there is a way to add an annotation in my Entity class instead.

astNode.text: I did a workaround for now, but I would still like to know if there is a way to add an annotation in my Entity class instead.

node.contents: Workaround is as follows: Add a method in the Relationship's repository interface, that extends JpaRepository.

astNode.text: Workaround is as follows: Add a method in the Relationship's repository interface, that extends JpaRepository.

elements.contents: public List<Relationship> findByChildIdAndChildType(Long childId, String childType);

units.rawText: public List<Relationship> findByChildIdAndChildType(Long childId, String childType);

node.contents: Then, in every service class for A, B, C entities, add relationship resource, and edit find and findAll or whatever methods by adding code that sets the relationships field.

astNode.text: Then, in every service class for A, B, C entities, add relationship resource, and edit find and findAll or whatever methods by adding code that sets the relationships field.

elements.contents: @Service @Transactional public class AService implements IAService { @Resource private IARepository aRepository; @Resource IRelationshipRepository relationshipRepository; @Override public A findOne(Long id) { A a = aRepository.findOne(id); List<Relationship> relationships = new ArrayList<Relationship>(); relationships = relationshipRepository.findByChildIdAndChildType(id, 'A'); a.setRelationships(relationships); return a; } // other fields and methods omitted.. }

node.contents: Hope this will help you.. if not please update your question with your entity model.

astNode.text: Hope this will help you.. if not please update your question with your entity model.

node.contents: I'm sorry, no, this is not at all what I was asking for. I need an annotation for my field (not for a local variable), so that it gets set when I get an instance bean of the entity class. I edited the question, I hope it's clear now.

astNode.text: I'm sorry, no, this is not at all what I was asking for. I need an annotation for my field (not for a local variable), so that it gets set when I get an instance bean of the entity class. I edited the question, I hope it's clear now.

node.contents: Considering relation_ship is your Relationship table and above described table is parent_child

astNode.text: Considering relation_ship is your Relationship table and above described table is parent_child

elements.contents: SQLQuery query = session.createSQLQuery( "SELECT r FROM relation_ship r INNER JOIN parent_child p ON r.id = p.ChildID and p.ChildType := ChildType").setParameter("ChildType","A"); List<Relationship> = query.list();

node.valueRep: "SELECT r FROM relation_ship r INNER JOIN parent_child p ON r.id = p.ChildID and p.ChildType := ChildType"
